Actinopolyspora alba is a species of bacteria that belongs to the phylum Actinobacteria. It is a Gram-positive, aerobic, and spore-forming actinomycete. Actinopolyspora alba was first isolated from a soil sample collected in China.

The cells of Actinopolyspora alba are typically rod-shaped and can form branched mycelium. The colony color on agar media can range from white to pale yellow. This bacterium is capable of growing at high salt concentrations, making it adapted to saline environments.

Actinopolyspora alba is known to produce various secondary metabolites, including antibiotics, which can have potential applications in the pharmaceutical industry. It is considered a halophilic bacterium, meaning it can thrive in high-salt conditions.

The genome of Actinopolyspora alba has been sequenced, providing insights into its metabolic capabilities and adaptations to its ecological niche. Further studies on this species may contribute to our understanding of microbial diversity and their potential biotechnological applications.
